awd_titl_txt: Establishing a core signaling mechanism for the multi-functional FERONIA receptor kinase
awd_abstract_narration:
The ultimate goal of the research is to understand how plants grow, develop and thrive even when under adverse environmental conditions, thus potentially augmenting society's ability to ensure sustainable agricultural productivity and ecological balance. To accomplish the goals of the research, a team of students comprised of undergraduates, doctoral students and postdoctoral associates will be trained to carry out a range of projects focused on a cell membrane located molecule, called FERONIA, known to play key roles in diverse aspects of plant growth and survival. These projects will provide them with training in biochemistry, cell biology and molecular biology, the basics of how cells and organisms function, which will enhance their ability to emerge as teachers and researchers. Workshops offering hands-on exposure to experiments related to the project and compatible to a high school laboratory will be offered to teachers in STEM who will also be offered further mentoring to encourage incorporation of some of the materials into their classroom exercises or discussions. Topics related to the research area will be incorporated into a teaching effort that fosters skills in science writing to inform the public. Together these activities should broaden society's pipeline for future scientists as well as improve public awareness of the scientific inquiry process and the importance of its products. Moreover, FERONIA is conserved among plant species; the knowledge and research materials generated by this project should stimulate interest and facilitate similar inquiries in agriculturally important crops and in efforts to ensure vibrant growth of plants in their native habitats, including under harsh conditions, thus with the potential to impact global issues such as food production and a sustainable ecology. 

Research supported by this award focuses on understanding how FERONIA, from the model plant Arabidopsis, controls a broad array of processes critical for plant growth, development and coping with environmental stresses. FERONIA belongs to a class of molecules called receptor kinases, which play key roles in sensing changes outside the cell and translating these signals to stimulate cellular responses appropriate for the incoming signals. Although the importance of receptor kinases has long been established in plants by voluminous research, the diverse functional roles carried out by FERONIA is striking and how it is accomplished remains puzzling. The goal of this project is to determine how FERONIA orchestrates what must be a complex network of biochemical and cell biological processes needed to execute its functions. In particular, the project seeks to elucidate a core signal transduction pathway capable of serving as a hub with which the various FER-regulated processes might be integrated. This core pathway, referred to as FER/LLG-ROPGEF-RAC/ROP, is comprised of FERONIA receptor kinase, its functional partner, a lipid-modified protein anchored on the cell membrane called LLG1, and their immediate cellular target ROPGEF, which activates key cytoplasmic signaling molecules, called RAC/ROP GTPases. Biochemical and microscopy-based experiments will be carried out in plants grown under normal growth conditions and when challenged by an environmental growth regulatory signal, a small peptide hormone called RALF1. Experiments are designed to examine how these molecules interact, the cellular and molecular consequences of these interactions and how they together might lead to various plant growth responses regulated by FERONIA. Together, results from this research should provide insight towards the mechanistic underpinning of how FERONIA mediates its diverse functional roles whereby furthering our knowledge about strategies employed by organisms for growth and survival.

por.por_cntn:
The FERONIA (named after the mythical goddess of fruitfulness) receptor kinase from Arabidopsis impacts a broad range of processes that support plant growth and development, mediate reproductive success, and provide resilience against threatening environmental conditions, such as incremental climate and pathogen attacks. A receptor kinase senses signals (e.g., changes in the environment) from outside the cell and instructs how the recipient cell responds to best take advantage of a favorable condition or to avoid and survive a threatening condition. The collective cellular responses often govern how a tissue, an organ, and even the entire organism would respond. FERONIA works together with a partner called LLG1. The overall goal of this project is to understand how FERONIA-LLG1 increases or decreases the capacity of many different cellular pathways in response to a signal. The best-characterized molecular signal, referred to as a ligand, that controls the activity of FERONIA-LLG1 is a small peptide called RALF. When RALF binds to FERONIA-LLG1, it alters its activity in supporting cell growth under normal conditions and mediating counteractions when under duress from the environment. The goal of this project centers on understanding how the interactions engaged by RALF1-FERONIA-LLG1 on the cell surface led to diverse cellular responses. The capacity of FERONIA-LLG1 to impact a broad range of plant processes provides an excellent opportunity to address how coordinated control of multiple and diverse cellular pathways is achieved  

Results from this project provided a key answer to our question. A well-established phenomenon at the cell surface is that cell surface receptors, once activated by interacting with their respective ligands, modulate their own activity by triggering endocytosis of the ligand-receptor complex. Endocytosis extracts the activated signaling complex from the cell membrane into the cell and reduces the activity of the activated cellular pathway to avoid an over-active response, which is harmful to cell health, e.g., converting healthy cells to become diseased. This process, called ligand-induced receptor endocytosis is usually specific, i.e., affecting only the ligand-receptor pair and the pathway it regulates. We discover that FER-LLG1, once triggered by RALF1 has the extraordinary ability to cause not only its own endocytosis but also promiscuously the endocytosis of numerous cell membrane-associated regulators of diverse cellular processes. Our results show that if plants are prevented from undergoing endocytosis, their capacity to remain resilient when encountering environmental stresses, such as elevated salinity or temperature, becomes severely compromised. These findings, therefore, solved a major puzzle in FERONIA biology and an important original goal of the project. 

This project also elucidated a novel cell surface phenomenon, liquid-liquid phase separation (LLPS) between RALF and pectin, a major sugar component of the cell wall, that might set a new paradigm for broader signal strategies. Efforts for this inquiry were prompted by the observation of another exceptional property of RALF-triggered FERONIA-LLG1-dependent promiscuous endocytosis. Typically, ligand-receptors are co-endocytosed. In the case of RALF-triggered FERONIA-LLG1 endocytosis, the ligand peptide remains outside the cell. LLPS refers to a process in which molecules (solutes) in a solution de-mix from the solvent and assume a phase with high solute concentrations and separable from the initial solvent. Studied extensively as a physical-chemical phenomenon, LLPS has emerged in recent years to be a major force for many biological processes; the high molecule concentrations achieved within the phase-separated condensates facilitate the initiation of many reactions. Pectin is a polymer of galacturonic acid (a derivative of the sugar galactose), and an important functional component of the cell wall, which juxtaposes the cell membrane. Pectin, RALF (secreted out of the cell), and FRONIA-LLG1, therefore, occur together at the cell wall-cell membrane interface. Our project established that RALF and pectin together undergo LLPS, and the RALF-pectin condensates assemble FERONIA, LLG1, and other receptors into membrane microdomains capable of simultaneously impacting the activities of multiple cellular pathways controlled by diverse receptors.  

Findings from this project provide important insight on the involvement of membrane microdomains in organizing signaling activities, which has remained a long-standing mystery in cell signaling studies. They will be foundational to a new phase of plant signal transduction studies. 

This project provided training for postdoctoral and Ph.D. students, preparing them for careers in research and science education. A diverse group of more than twenty undergraduates participated in the project. Several went on to graduate and medical studies and were co-authorships in publications. One, from an American minority group that is also under-represented in STEM, will launch a Ph.D. study in September 2024. All trainees were also provided opportunities in mentoring or mutual mentoring to prepare them as mentors to future generations.
